did.repository: University of Pennsylvania, Rare Book and Manuscript Library

bioghist.p: Lawrence Robert Klein (born 1920) is a Nobel Prize-winning American economist. He earned his bachelor's degree from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1942 and his Ph.D. in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1944. After positions at the University of Chicago, University of Michigan, and Oxford University, he joined the Department of Economics at the University of Pennsylvania in 1958. He was named the Benjamin Franklin Professor of Economics and Finance at the Wharton School in 1968. In the early 1960s Klein became the leader of the major "Brookings-SSRC Project", to construct a detailed econometric model to forecast the short-term development of the American economy. He also founded Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates (WEFA) and was the initiator of their LINK project. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economics in 1980.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional papers of Lawrence Klein. Much of the material in the collection relates to Klein's work on Project LINK. Materials include incoming and outgoing correspondence, drafts of Klein's papers, articles, reports, and addresses; reprints and photocopies of papers and reports by others; notes, minutes, and reports from various conferences and symposia; student papers, dissertations, and letters of recommendation; and course syllabi, exam questions, and lecture notes.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
